choices: Stairway
Corridor
1.content:
You wake up feeling groggy, thinking you may have been drugged.

“Where am I? What the hell happened?” you think to yourself. “The last thing I remember
was buying a pack of Mentos from the newsstand on my way to work this morning!”
You manage to get to your feet and look around. You are standing on a platform at an
unfamiliar subway station. There isn’t a soul in sight. The station looks like a crumbling
relic of a time gone by, like something out of a post-nuclear sci-fi movie. The only signs of
civilization are a couple of rats gnawing at the contents of an overturned trash bin.

After the initial shock of unfamiliarity, you begin to calm down. You revel in the quiet and
solitude, you always were a loner, even as a child. After your father walked out when you
were only ten, your mother routinely left you home alone at night while she went out to
earn enough money to pay the rent on your roach infested apartment. Being too poor to
have a television, you often fell asleep with the music of the local progressive jazz station
and monotone droning of their announcer for company...

You decide to end your daydream and start walking. You have two options: at one end of the platform is a narrow dimly lit corridor, at the other a wide staircase leading downward. The faint sound of a saxophone drifts up from the stairwell.

"Right or wrong, boy, make a decision!" Your father's words echo in your head. He’d always made his choices on the spur of the moment, probably including the day he'd
abandoned his family.
1.title: Only the Lonely

choices: Turn Back
Continue the Descent
11.content:
You approach the stairwell and descend, lead onward by the strains of the saxophone.
"Coltrane," you say to yourself. "Dad used to play that song."

You hear a scrabbling noise and turn around, notice that the rats from the trash bin are
following you. "And what am I, the goddam pied piper?" you say. "Eat up boys, put some
meat on your bones." you say, tossing them a half eaten candy bar you had stuffed into
your jacket pocket earlier. Rats are no strangers to you, having fed one that lived under your kitchen sink table scraps as a boy, being careful not to let your mother catch you at it.

"Rats are filthy beasts!" she had said, but she wouldn't allow you to have any other pets.
She’d even refused to let you keep a poor starving mongrel pup you had once found.
"Just what we need around here, another mouth to feed. Get rid of it right now, or you
won't be having any supper!" She had said. You still remember putting the puppy out on
the sidewalk, how it had whined pitifully and scratched at the door as you walked
dejectedly back up the stairs.

You sat at the table that night twiddling a fork through a plate of half congealed macaroni
and cheese. "Eat up, boy, put some meat on your bones!" your mother had said, lighting
another Lucky off the butt of her previous one. "Got to grow up big and strong so you
can get a job, I’m not gonna be here to feed you forever!"
After supper that night you went back downstairs to check, but the puppy had wandered
off in search of better prospects.

"See! You didn't feed that dog, so he left," your mother said. "Dogs are the same as
people, they all want something. You might think they're your friends, but if you don't give
them what they want they'll leave you."
"Is that what happened with daddy?" you asked. You can still feel the sting of the back of
her hand across your face in reply. You realize now that she thought you were being
sarcastic, but at the time it was only a child's innocent question.
The stairs seem to be endless, and it is getting colder as you descend. “Maybe I should
turn back?” you think.
11.title: Descending Into the Past

choices: Break through the barrier.
Give up and go back down the stairs.
111.content:
Turning back, you climb the stairs to the next landing. You find your way blocked by an
invisible barrier. You extend your arms, pushing, feeling for a break. You laugh, realizing
that you probably look like a common street mime doing this. You recall a joke about a
mime who was murdered by being placed in a glass box in a park. The passerbys thought
he was only acting as he suffocated. You laugh as you remember this.

"Yes, it's a sick world, and I'm a part of it." you say to yourself. You pull a cigarette out
of a crumbled Lucky Strike packet and flick the lighter you stole from your father as a kid,
the only thing you have to remember him by.
111.title: Marcel Marceau

choices: Let  her follow you.
Tell her your better alone.
1112.content:
As you descend further you start to notice the formation of ice on the walls and the roof.
"Where the fuck am I heading." you think as you snuggle deeper into your coat.
A wind starts to pick up and whistle around your ears, bringing with it the strains of the saxaphone music you heard earlier. The music is strange yet somehow familiar. Your not to sure if it's some old tune that you have heard before.
The wind picks up and as it does the saxaphone gets louder. The stairwell is still descending downwards with no sign of ending.
"This is getting just a bit to crazy." you mutter to yourself.
"Oh. You get used to it."
Spinning around you stare at a small girl who has appeared behind you apparently out of nowhere. In her hand is a small beat up rag doll, its left arm missing.
"Can I come to mister, I've lost my mum and I can't find my way home."
1112.title: A New Face

choices: Engage him in battle with your light-saber.
Sing while he plays the sax.
112.content:
“No, I’m not gonna give up that easily, gotta see who’s at the bottom of these steps.” you
think. You turn up the frayed collar of your denim jacket and continue down the stairs.
The saxophone is getting louder, the Coltrane tune wailing into the lonely night.

You finally reach the bottom of the stairs and look out onto the platform. Ahead of you,
playing the sax, is an old man wearing an umpire suit and a cheap plastic Darth Vader
mask.

As you approach the man stops playing. "Where am I?" you ask.

"The Cleveland Underground." he replies tersely.

"And who are you?" you ask.

"Isn't it obvious? ... I'm your father, Luke!" He responds, removing the mask.
112.title: The Umpire Strikes Back

choices: You burn the side of his face.
He grabs the lighter and pins your arms to your side.
1121.content:
His response brings back memories of your childhood and enrages you...

After seeing "Star Wars" you used to have light-saber battles with your younger
brother in your room at night in the dark using stolen cigarette lighters. One night
you got too close and burned your brother's arm and he started crying. Your dad
came stumbling into the room, drunk as usual, and your brother told on you:

"You wanna play with fire, boy? Here!" Dad grabbed onto your fingers and seared
your hand with his lighter. "Surrender to the Dark Force! Heh-heh.”
“This hurts me more then it does you." he said, as you cried in agony...

Although it was long ago, you still carry the scar from that night on the back of
your hand. You see it every time you look at your watch.

Now you pull your lighter from your pocket, determined to pay him back for the
injuries of your childhood. You turn the flame up all the way and flash it in his
face: "This'll hurt ME more than it does YOU, Dad!"
1121.title: Surrender to the Dark Force?

choices: Your father offers you a drink.
1122.content:
You're speechless, you don't know what to say to him. You haven't seen him since
he walked out on you and your mom years ago.

Saying nothing further, your father dons the mask again and resumes playing the
saxophone, a perfect rendition of Coltrane's take of the old song "Favorite
Things".

Impulsively, you start singing. Not the original words of the song, but cynical
lyrics of your own, inspired by remembrances of your childhood:
"Raindrops on beer cans and roaches in kitchens,
Half empty rum bottles, drunk in one sitting,
Broken toys fixed up with duct tape and string,
These are a few of my favorite things..."
1122.title: Favorite Things

choices: You are crushed to death under the rubble.
You are trapped in the underground.
11221.content:
He stops playing the sax and removes a half empty pint of Jim Beam from his jacket
pocket. "Here you go son, a sip of this'll cheer you up." he says, holding it out.

Although you know you shouldn't, you grab the bottle from him and greedily drink it all
down. The harshness of the whiskey makes you start to cough, but you stifle it and wipe
your mouth with the back of your sleeve, then unthinkingly hand the empty bottle back to
him.

"Heh-heh, didn't leave any for me? Guess I was right in figuring you'd have a taste for the
stuff too by now. The apple doesn't fall far from the tree, does it son."

You don't know what to say to him so you remain silent. You are content just to feel the
warmth of the alcohol flowing from your gut into your bloodstream. It's been such a long
time since you'd fallen off the wagon, you'd almost forgotten how good that buzz could
feel.

Suddenly a loud rumbling sound begins to build behind you and the ground starts to shake
violently. Pieces of the ceiling begin falling , you run down the platform trying to escape
the falling brickwork and concrete.
11221.title: Message in a Bottle.

112211.content:
I guess you just had to click on this link to see if I really meant it, didn't you? Well I did,
so here's how it goes:

You try your best to escape but there is nowhere safe to run. You are buried under tons of
concrete and brick rubble as the subway tunnel collapses on top of you. The last thing you
are thinking before your life essence dissipates is "Did I remember to feed the dog?" Funny
the mundane things people think of in their last moments on earth...

In this thread there is no afterlife, no "Stairway to Heaven" (or Hell) waiting for you.
You're just dead, that's it. If this ending is too dark for you, you can always go back to the
previous chapter and try your luck with the other link... If only it were that easy in real
life.
112211.title: No Surprises Here

choices: Panic and start digging madly at the rubble.
112212.content:
As suddenly as it started, the shaking stops. You look around in panic and see that the
exits have all been buried in rubble. You are now trapped deep under ground, with no
visible means of escape.

You no longer feel the glow of the whiskey, nor can you even taste it. Your father is
nowhere in sight, and you begin to wonder if he was ever there at all. "Was It all a
Dream?" "Am I Crazy?!, Going Mad?!" ...the lights on the subway platform begin to
flicker and fade... "Is Anyone Out There?" "HELP MEEEE!!!"
112212.title: The Edge of Sanity

choices: Back out of the tunnel before it caves in.
Dig fast and try to get through before it caves in.
1122121.content:
Although somewhere in the back of your disturbed mind you realize it is probably
futile, you claw insanely at the massive pile of debris, screaming: "HELP! SAVE
ME! I DON'T WANNA DIE! GET ME OUTA HERE!"

Eventually your voice is too raspy to scream and you find yourself muttering
hoarsely as you dig, over and over, "I-Think-I-Can I-Think-I-Can I-Think-I-Can",
remembering "The Little Engine That Could". It was a favorite bedtime story of
yours, your father used to read to you often, at least when he was sober enough to
do so.

Your fingers are bleeding and raw and you have torn off two of the nails on your
right hand, but the pain no longer even registers. You keep on digging, as the light
continues to fade.

After what seems like eons you realize that somehow you have managed to dig a
tunnel several feet deep into the rubble, and can see a glimmer of light shining
through a small space ahead. The debris above your head is beginning to shift and
rumble though, and you fear that it may cave in on you at any moment.
1122121.title: I-Think-I-Can...

choices: He's Hallucinating
He Finds Another Way Out
11221211.content:
I know the tunnel is going to cave at any moment, so I back out just in time to hear it come crashing down. The white and gray dust cover me in a plume of smoke. Wiping away at my clothes, I cough the miniscule particles out of my lungs. That's when I hear the sax again. I spin around and see my dad standing there with a stupid grin on his face.

"You were here? Why didn't you help?"

"I did help you, Boy. Are you lying crushed beneath the rubble?" He replied with a chuckle.

Not understanding what was so damn funny, I turn to try and find another way out.

"Well, how do we get out of here?" I ask, no longer hiding my anger or fear.

"Son, let me tell you. There are a few ways out, but none of those ways are better than where you're at right now. One way leads to flames licking your face, another to hungry rats wanting to feed off your flesh."

"What? What the hell are you talking about? No wonder Mom didn't care that you left. You're crazier than she is!"

"HA! Left? Yea, Son. I left alright. But it damn sure wasn't from choice. Why do you think you sing that little diddly that you made up? Where do you think it came from?"

"Maybe, from the times you tied Mom up and duct taped her mouth."

"You better rethink that, Son. I never tied your mom up. You're remembering when she tied me to a chair. I was drugged--couldn't fight back. Son, your mom didn't just tie me up that night, she tied me up and killed me. She buried me under the shed, beneath the concrete floor. Why do you think she won't let you have a dog? She don't want it scratching up things better left buried."

"What the hell are you talking about old man? If you were dead, how am I talking to you?"

"Son, haven't you wondered how you just magically found me? I'm sorry to be the one to tell you this, but you've joined me. Son, you're dead."

"I don't have time for this bullshit!" But even saying that I knew something ringed true in his words. I can't be dead, can I? I try to think what happened to me before I was on the subway, but for the life of me, I can't remember. Why didn't I stay on the subway and get off somewhere I was familiar with? And why in the hell did I go down the stairwell?

I bury my face in my hands. Nothing makes sense. I look up and to ask dad if we are dead, then why can't we just walk through the damn walls! "Dad, if we're... Dad? Dad? Where the hell did you go?" I jump up and run all through the little area he just was. There' no one, nothing.

I'm losing my mind. I must not be getting oxygen. I'm having freaking hallucinations!
11221211.title: Back out of the tunnel before it caves in.

choices: Go through the door,
11221212.content:
Although you realize it is risky and you should probably turn back you continue to
dig, trying desperately to break through before the tunnel collapses. You manage
to open a hole about a foot across, almost wide enough to squeeze through, and
you see an open passageway ahead.

"I-Know-I-Can I-Know-I-Can!" you begin to shout as you dig, invigorated by the
prospect of freedom...

But in this story, as in Life, there is a price to be paid for impatience...

With a loud roar the tunnel collapses above you as the icy hand of fear grips your
chest... It seems as if it's happening in slow motion as the tons of rock and broken
concrete begin to squeeze the air of life from your lungs.

But just as suddenly as it started, it stops. Although you are trapped in the rubble,
the space in front of you is now cleared into the passageway. Somehow, you think,
miraculously you have been spared.

As the dust settles you see a short middle-aged guy wearing faded jeans and a
"Hooters" t-shirt approaching. "Here, let me give you a hand!" he says, as he
begins to work at the rubble. A younger, thin, black man joins him and soon they
have you untrapped and pull you to your feet. You notice that amazingly, you feel
no pain as you turn to thank them.

You recognize them, a couple of guys from work you haven't seen around in a
while. "Bill? Darrel? What are you guys doing here?" you ask.
"The question is, my man, what are YOU doing here?" Darrel quips.
You feel a chill as you remember. The reason you haven't seen them around lately
is they are both dead. Bill from a heart attack last July, Darrel from cancer a year
earlier.

"Then I guess I didn't make it through the tunnel after all, did I?" you ask, as
reality sinks in.

"It all depends on how you look at it." Bill replies.

"So, what do I do next?" you ask.

"Go through the door straight ahead. And good luck, my man!" Darrel says.

“Thanks.” you reply.
11221212.title: With a Little Help From My Friends

choices: Sing along with Jerry.
Try your luck with the tunnel.
112212121.content:
You walk through and the door slams ominously behind you, there’s no turning
back. Ahead you see an overweight bearded man with bright red skin, sitting on a
rock playing an acoustic guitar, with flames and smoke behind him.

"...if I get home before daylight, just might get some sleep tonighhht." he finishes
playing, and leans the guitar against the rock.
"Uhhh, Satan?" you inquire?
"No, just another “friend of the devil”, so to speak." He chuckles. "The red skin
fools people, just a side effect of the heat and flames down here."

"This has got to be a mistake, I really don’t belong in Hell. Isn’t there some kind of
way to get out of here?" you ask him.

"Well, on your right there's a small tunnel that is supposed to be a way to escape.
I've been told it's infested with rats and poisonous spiders, though. The last guy
that went in didn't come back, so I guess he might have made it out, although I did
hear some screaming. I haven't had the balls to try it myself. Figured I'd just kick
back, smoke my pipe, play a few tunes, and see what happens next. We've got all
of eternity, you're welcome to join me, sing along a little if you want to."
112212121.title: Friend of the Devil

choices: Allow yourself to be led away by Satan.
1122121211.content:
“You who choose to lead must follow, but if you fall, you fall alone
If you should stand, then who’s to guide you. If I knew a way, I would take you
home..."

You realize the lines of the song are more meaningful now, in light of your present
predicament.

Suddenly Satan appears in all his glory, with a goofy demonic sidekick who looks
like Danny DeVito.

"You're just having waaay to much fun!" the devil roars. "Come here guys, I've got
a job for you to do!"
1122121211.title: Ripple

choices: Pick up your brush and get to work.
Hit Danny DeVito with the brush and run away
11221212111.content:
Satan leads you down a long dimly lit corridor, walking mile after mile, past locked
chambers filled with wailing souls being tormented in God knows what kind of horrible
ways. Jerry starts lagging behind and complaining : "Hey, I'm not in shape for all this
walking, man! Couldn't we take a break and get something to eat?"

But there is no rest for the wicked in this story. Danny DeVito circles around behind him
and jabs him in the ass with his pitchfork: "Stop your griping and get moving, lard butt!
We're almost there!"

You turn a corner and the corridor opens up and ends on top of a cliff overlooking a huge
deserted beach beneath a star filled alien sky. There is this beautiful huge
oval-shaped-swirly-galaxy-thing visible overhead, kind of like what Jodie Foster saw in the
movie "Contact". It would almost be a perfect vision of cosmic awareness and beauty, if
only it weren't for the disgusting smell of excrement emanating from it.

"My God! stench is horrible!" you exclaim. "What the hell is it?"

"That's God's Toilet Bowl, and you two guys are gonna clean it!" Satan replies, handing
you and Jerry a couple of absolutely huge impossibly long-handled toilet brushes and a 55
gallon drum filled with Lysol.

"No way! That would take an eternity!" you respond.

"Like you don't have the time?" Satan quips. "I'll leave Danny here to supervise. Now
GET TO WORK!" he commands, as he lifts his wings and vanishes into a cloud of
sulphurous smoke.
11221212111.title: Tidy Bowl Blues

choices: Get hit with a lightning bolt,
1122121212.content:
Deciding to take your chances, you crawl into the tunnel.
“Good luck, man!” Jerry calls to you.
“Thanks... AAAAIIEEE!!” You scream as the bottom of the tunnel suddenly
drops away, sending you falling, literally, into the pits of Hell. You land in a heap
on the ground in front of Satan.
"Ahhh, I’ve been waiting for you.” Satan says. “You know not many people
realize this, but I'm a Zen master."
He quickly pulls a large machete from his belt and lops off your right hand. You
stand there shocked, as the hand floats above you. The hand begins opening and
closing rythmically, fingers making a repeated clopping sound as they meet the
palm.
"That is the sound of one hand clapping." the devil says, chuckling. He reaches up,
grabs the hand and pushes it back onto your forearm, where it reattaches
seamlessly.
"Can't have my right hand man walking around without his right hand, can I?" he
says " I have important work for you to do."

The devil hands you a garden rake and a hefty bag and points at the ground. "See
all of these demon turds lying around? I need you to bag these and put them out by
the curb for trash pick up."
"But I’m your right hand man! I thought I'd get to do some fun type evil and sin
stuff!" you complain.
"Yeah, maybe later, but for now there's work to be done, and if you don't get
raking I'm gonna fry your ass with a lightning bolt!"
1122121212.title: A Hell of a Job

choices: Finish raking and go eat dinner,
11221212121.content:
ZZZAP !!!! "Ow, hey, that hurts! I didn't think you'd really do it, I thought you
were kidding!"

"Satan never kids!" the devil replies. "Now get to work, or the next bolt will get
you in the balls!"

You pick up the rake and dejectedly begin the task. "Boy it must be nice, being the
boss and getting others to do all of your dirty work." you comment.

"Are you kidding? I promised the wife I'd fix the leak in the bathroom plumbing
and paint the kitchen by the end of this weekend. Her mother's coming to stay with
us for a while, she'll be here on Monday. and you're complaining about having to
rake up the yard!" the devil says.

"Why don't you get some of your demons to do the plumbing for you?" you ask.

"They haven't got the brains God promised a retarded piss ant! You can't teach
them to use indoor plumbing, let alone fix it! Hell, about all they're good for is
poking the poor damned souls with pitchforks, and some of them can't even figure
which side of the fork to use! Well, I'd better get to work on that plumbing, no rest
for the wicked. Come on up the house for dinner after you finish here, my wife
makes a hell of a tuna casserole." The devil says, as he walks away.
11221212121.title: Antwerp's Placebo

choices: Sneak back in to visit Satan's daughter.
Go to sleep.
112212121211.content:
You bag up the last of the turds, set them by the curb, and go clean yourself up using the
garden hose on the side of the house. You go in through the back door and sit down to
dinner with Satan, his wife, and their teenage daughter.

The casserole isn't bad, just kind of bland. "Got any salt?" you ask. "No, this is Hell, you
can't have any salt!" Satan replies. The daughter giggles at this, but later slips a paper
McDonald's salt packet to you under the table and eyes you somewhat seductively. You
smile and give her a look of thanks, and pour the salt on your food when the devil and his
wife aren't looking.

After dinner, Satan hands you an old horse blanket and walks you outside. "You can sleep
in the barn with the demons tonight. And don't get any ideas about messing around with
my daughter or there'll be hell to pay!" he exclaims.

"OK, sure." you reply, as you trudge off to the barn.
112212121211.title: Have You Heard the one about...

choices: A  bent man comes out of hiding to greet you
You pass by a mirror, that causes you to stop
You hear a noise that is unfamiliar
You decide what happens next
12.content: You step gingerly in the direction of the corridor. As you near it you can see glimpses of rats in between the walls as they scatter by quickly. A smell of rot drifts into you nostrils making your stomach feel queasy. You have seen friendlier places.
12.title: The corridor

info.brief_description: ...The last thing you remember was buying a pack of Mentos your way to work.
info.description: You find yourself at an unfamiliar subway station, a victim of amnesia. This story starts out on the dark side, but it lightens up later, on some of the threads. It's an emotional tragedy/fantasy/comedy kinda tale. You're welcome to follow along and add chapters. Enjoy!
